newsitem.title: JAPAN: Key cash JGB yield rises after strong output data.
newsitem.headline: Key cash JGB yield rises after strong output data.

text.p: The yield of the benchmark 182nd Japanese government bond rose on Tuesday after September industrial output data came in toward the higher end of the market's expectations.

A trust bank trader said he felt the strong forecasts for manufacturers' output in October, and the prediction of only a minor month-on-month drop off in November, also confirmed that the economy was still recovering.
The yield of the benchmark 182nd JGB stood at 2.640 percent as of 0702 GMT, up from the previous day's 2.610 percent
Industrial production in September increased a preliminary 1.0 percent from the previous month on a seasonally adjusted basis, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) said on Tuesday.
Manufacturers' output is seen increasing by 4.0 percent in October month on month on a seasonally adjusted basis, while it is seen dropping by 1.9 percent in November month on month.

Earlier in the afternoon, the yield of the benchmark 182nd JGB fell to 2.590 percent, the lowest since December 12, 1995. A trader for a city bank's securities affiliate said buying of cash JGBs by investors fuelled the fall in the benchmark yield.
The trader said foreign financial institutions and local city banks were detected buying the 184th and 190th 10-year JGBs.

The brief fall in the benchmark JGB yield was due probably to dealers' activity, based on speculation of strong demand for the six-year JGBs offered via the Finance Ministry's auction, a trader for a long-term credit bank's securities affiliate said.
MOF offered 500 billion yen worth of 2.0 percent six-year JGBs through a price-competitive auction on Tuesday.
The lowest price of the JGBs was 100.20, while the average price was 100.21, MOF said.

Traders said there had been talk in the market that the New Financial Stabilisation Fund, which was set up as part of a government scheme to solve the financial problems of failed mortgage companies, would buy the new six-year JGBs.
The first trader said such purchases were not actually detected, however.

"If the coupon rate had been set at 1.9 percent they probably would have been able to pick them up at under par. They have a rule saying they can't go after over-par bonds. When the bonds were offered with a two percent coupon rate, they seem to have decided not to pursue the bonds," he said.
Key December JGB futures ended at 124.50, down from 124.74 on Monday. Turnover was 52,196 contracts.
A trader for a trust bank's securities affiliate said the December's fall was due to position-adjustment sales ahead of the release of industrial output data.
Finance Minister Wataru Kubo said on Tuesday: "There is no need to formulate a large supplementary budget which includes investment in public works."
The third trader said the market will not view reports of a possible extra budget as a sell factor until more specific details are given.-- Masayuki Kitano, Tokyo Treasury Desk.
